  • Element
com.munkei

Annotation Type CommandLineOption


  • @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
@Target(value=FIELD)
public @interface CommandLineOption
    An annotation to use for command line options.

    All elements are optional. Thus the simplest usage is: 

     @CommandLineOption
    
 private Boolean verbose;
    The above will match the option --verbose when parsing (JArgP.parse(java.lang.String[])), and if it is present, the field verbose (of the "subject", see JArgP.JArgP(java.lang.Object)) will be set to true.

    If you want the command line option to use the next argument as a value for a field, make the field something other than a Boolean. Values are converted in Option.convert(java.lang.String, java.lang.Class), see its documentation for details.

    To configure the specifics of the command line option and how it is parsed, see each element:

    • To specify which command line options match a field, see names() and pattern().
    • To specify how the documentation for the field is printed (JArgP.printUsage(java.io.PrintStream)), see placeholder(), description(), defaultValue() and defaultValue().
    Since:
    0.0.1
    Author:
    Theo 'Biffen' Willows
    See Also:
    JArgP

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      String defaultValue
      A default value.
      String description
      A description of the option to use for the usage text.
      String[] names
      The names of the option.
      boolean opposite
      Creates a --no-[...] alias that sets it to false.
      String pattern
      For complex names match this pattern.
      String placeholder
      Text to use as a placeholder when printing the usage.
      String setter
      Specifies a method to set the value.
      String shortPattern
      For complex names match this pattern.

    • Element Detail

      • names

        public abstract String[] names
        The names of the option. These names will be accepted as options when parsing.

        If no names are specified (and no pattern() is specified), the name of the field itself is used.

        Single character names will be short options ( -[...]), others will be long options ( --[...]), with the exception of -, which will be just that.

        See Also:
        pattern()
        Default:
        {}

      • setter

        public abstract String setter
        Specifies a method to set the value. Must take either two String parameters, where the first one is the name and the second one is the value: 
        <setter>(String name, String value)
        or a single String parameter that is the value: 
        <setter>(String value)

        For multiples (Collections) it is assumed the setter appends a single value.

        One reason to use a setter would be to do some kind of validation of the value. You may throw an exception in the setter if the value is considered invalid. E.g. an ArgumentParsingException, but any type can be used, just make sure to catch it wherever you call JArgP.parse(java.lang.String[]).

        If not used, members will be set directly.

        Default:
        ""

      • pattern

        public abstract String pattern
        For complex names match this pattern. Patterns will be matched after names and aliases.

        E.g: [0-9]+ for options like -1, -2, etc.

        See Also:
        shortPattern(), names()
        Default:
        ""

      • shortPattern

        public abstract String shortPattern
        For complex names match this pattern. shortPatterns are matched against short options (--[...]). Patterns will be matched after names and aliases.

        E.g: [0-9]+ for options like -1, -2, etc.

        See Also:
        pattern()
        Default:
        ""

      • opposite

        public abstract boolean opposite
        Creates a --no-[...] alias that sets it to false.

        Switches only.

        Default:
        false

      • placeholder

        public abstract String placeholder
        Text to use as a placeholder when printing the usage.

        E.g. for an option called file one might set the placeholder to "FILE", to get a usage like: 

        --file FILE

        The default is "VALUE".

        Only used for options that take a value, i.e. not Booleans.

        See Also:
        JArgP.printUsage(java.io.PrintStream)
        Default:
        "VALUE"

      • description

        public abstract String description
        A description of the option to use for the usage text.
        See Also:
        JArgP.printUsage(java.io.PrintStream)
        Default:
        ""

      • defaultValue

        public abstract String defaultValue
        A default value. Will be documented in the usage text. Will be set by JArgP.parse(java.lang.String[]) to any member that has not been set by the arguments.
        See Also:
        JArgP.printUsage(java.io.PrintStream)
        Default:
        ""
